body:
### Problem

Formatting some continuous lines with efm-langserver, text lines are reversed.

It depends on the commit: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/2ce4a4d91e4abee0aab8b98c47eea9fbd4849ba6 and the issue: #29202.

Maybe the changes in the commit is intended to conform to specifications of LSP, but they looks like not still enough.
(Specs doesn't require sorting of text-edits)
So I don't know that which product (efm, Neovim or VSCode?) should fix the bug.

### Steps to reproduce

#### Prepare environment

We needs nvim-lspconfig, efm-langserver and jq for example (in Linux):

```console
$ export NVIM_APPNAME=nvim_issue_29392
$ NVIM_APPDIR="$HOME/.config/$NVIM_APPNAME"
$ EFM_NAME=efm-langserver_v0.0.53_linux_amd64
$ JQ_NAME=jq-linux-amd64 

$ mkdir -p "$NVIM_APPDIR/bin"
$ git clone https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig "$NVIM_APPDIR/rtp/nvim-lspconfig"
$ curl -Lo "$NVIM_APPDIR/bin/efm.tar.gz" "https://github.com/mattn/efm-langserver/releases/download/v0.0.53/$EFM_NAME.tar.gz"
$ curl -Lo "$NVIM_APPDIR/bin/jq" "https://github.com/jqlang/jq/releases/download/jq-1.7.1/$JQ_NAME"
$ chmod +x "$NVIM_APPDIR/bin/jq"
$ cd "$NVIM_APPDIR/bin"
$ tar -xvzf efm.tar.gz
$ mv $EFM_NAME/efm-langserver .
```

#### Setup neovim

And set-up nvim like below (`~/.config/nvim_issue_29392/init.lua`):

```
vim.opt.rtp:append("~/.config/nvim_issue_29392/rtp/nvim-lspconfig")

local lspconfig = require("lspconfig")
lspconfig.efm.setup({
  init_options = {
    documentFormatting = true,
  },
  settings = {
    languages = {
      json = { {
        formatStdin = true,
        formatCommand = "jq .",
      } },
    },
  },
})
```

#### Reproduce in Neovim

Prepare target file:

```json:foo.json
  {
    "foo": "bar"
  }
```

Start neovim:

```console
$ export NVIM_APPNAME=nvim_issue_29392
$ export PATH="$HOME/.config/$NVIM_APPNAME/bin:$PATH"
$ nvim foo.json
```

Call `lua vim.lsp.buf.format()`.

And get the invalid result:

```
}
  "foo": "bar"
{
```

### Expected behavior

Formatted right:

```json
{
  "foo": "bar"
}
```


### Neovim version (nvim -v)

v0.11.0-dev-b0c336e

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

no

### Operating system/version

Arch Linux

### Terminal name/version

WezTerm

### $TERM environment variable

xterm-256color

### Installation

Build from repo

comment_data.body:
> Maybe the changes in the commit is intended to conform to specifications of LSP, but they looks like not still enough.
(Specs doesn't require sorting of text-edits)

For what it's worth, the spec specifically says that the order of edits matters. The language server I run sends them in a specific order, and they work fine in VSCode. Neovim is the only client that we've had this issue with.
Just to be clear: I am not sure if the problem @scohen is facing is the same as the one caused by the compatibility with efm-langserver.

My take is that the client shouldn't be reordering edits, neovim's client does. Right now, my LS doesn't have a problem with neovim, the commits mentioned in the bug fixed the problems we were having, but I felt that was not a correct fix.
Maybe it should be reported as another issue.
I also have kind of the same problem with tsserver after https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/2ce4a4d91e4abee0aab8b98c47eea9fbd4849ba6, https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/29286

@kyoh86 the PR that was landed causing this issue actually is more inline with the LSP spec. The commit makes it so that text edits with the same start position aren't applied in reverse anymore and are applied in the order that they are received.

For text edits that have different start positions, from the LSP spec, they should be provided in reverse order, i.e. edits provided starting from the bottom of the file. If they aren't provided in reverse order, the sorting enforces that. Again, this doesn't apply to text edits with the same start position.

I was worried that this might cause issues because the bug was introduced close to 3 years ago and LSPs that were developed in that timeframe specifically for Neovim and tested against the errant code would have issues.

If you provide the debug logs for your particular case, I can check to see it is relying on the errant code. 

I think we'd need @mfussenegger or @hrsh7th to weigh in on whether the "fix" should be reverted or if LSPs relying on the errant code should be forced to update to be more inline with spec. It's a bit of a tough call, but I lean toward the latter.

> I was worried that this might cause issues because the bug was introduced close to 3 years ago and LSPs that were developed in that timeframe specifically for Neovim and tested against the errant code would have issues.

As you say, and quite sadly, the specification has already been rebuffed by Microsoft (in tsserver, for example), the party that formulated it.
But even if it is the "correct" implementation of the specification, if users will get destructive results, I think we should try to cooperate with LS to avoid such a tragedy.
Of course, I understand that the effort involved is significant, and I am not going to ask for it unilaterally. I would be willing to request tsserver to correct this discrepancy myself.

@alcolmenar I see. thanks!
I'll try to report to efm-langserver repository.

NOTE:
Vim (with [vim-lsp](https://github.com/prabirshrestha/vim-lsp)) and [Helix](https://github.com/helix-editor/helix) doesn't applies them in reverse.
Maybe VSCode also.
We need to request such other clients to fix the order, like  https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/2ce4a4d91e4abee0aab8b98c47eea9fbd4849ba6 and the issue https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/29202.

It's going to be a very long road...

coc.nvim also doesn't applies them in reverse.
Now only the Neovim is buggy. (But it's as per LSP specifications)

I reported other clients:

https://github.com/helix-editor/helix/issues/11174
https://github.com/neoclide/coc.nvim/issues/5087
https://github.com/prabirshrestha/vim-lsp/issues/1566

I'm waiting their response.

title: Text edits from efm-langserver are applied in reverse
